comment: rv; was not an improvement, added unnecessary relativistic bias to definition. previous version was rightly silent (and thus neutral) on who if anyone gets to make the differentiation between good and bad.

diff.*:
Line 7: Line 7:  
{{lead too short|date=June 2012}}
 
{{lead too short|date=June 2012}}
    −
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those perceptions by either individuals and/or group dogmas in consideration of what is deemed "good" (or [[right and wrong|right]]) and those that are deemed "bad" (or wrong), in varying degrees of opinion, and adherence to particular perceptions of types of proper moral behaviors, often related to cause and effect circumstance. The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. opposition to that which is good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
+
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or wrong). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. opposition to that which is good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
